Award.AwardTitle: Catalysis Chemistry Involving Nucleosides and Related Heterocycles
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division at the National Science Foundation supports the research and pedagogical activities of Prof. Mahesh K. Lakshman at The City College and The City University of New York. Professor Lakshman's research involves the chemical modification of nucleosides and purine derivatives as well as closely related heterocycles, using catalysis methodology. Studies are conducted on metal-catalyzed carbon-carbon and carbon-nitrogen bond-formation methodologies. There are several aims of the research: chemoselective and room-temperature transformations of nucleosides, design of new ligands for modulation of catalytic conversions, development of benzotriazolyl nucleoside analogues, and use of pyrimidine, quinazoline, and purine as potentially disposable handles for functionalization of organic molecules. Professor Lakshman collaborates with researchers at several national and international institutions to access the activity of the new nucleosides and related heterocycles created as part of this project. The research has various levels of complexity and students at all educational levels participate in the program. In addition, this research has led to opportunities for outreach to local schools and colleges.

Metal-catalyzed reactions offer a state-of-the-art approach to assembling complex molecular structures, often not accessible by other means. Nucleosides and purines are highly important biomolecules with applications in biochemistry, biology, and medicine. Metal-catalyzed reactions of nucleosides and purines allow for ready diversification of these biochemical scaffolds and provide access to previously unknown molecular architectures. Metal catalysis also offers access to molecules that resemble nucleosides, and the intrinsic chemical reactivity of purines and related heterocycles can potentially be exploited in new ways. New nucleosides and related heterostructures that are produced as part of this research are evaluated at several schools of pharmacy and medical institutions as potential anti-viral or anti-HIV medicines as well as treatments for cardiovascular disease and cancer. Students at various educational levels, including those from local middle and high schools and colleges, gain training in contemporary chemistry and professional preparation by participating in this research project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nucleosides are some of the most ubiquitous biomolecules found in all living systems and they constitute the fundamental building blocks of genetic material. They are divided into two classes: purine nucleosides and pyrimidine nucleosides, and these are further divided into deoxyribonucleosides found in DNA, and ribonucleosides found in RNA.  Because of their wide prevalence in living systems it is obvious that these molecules can be used to modulate biological activities in living systems. For example, purines and their derivatives modulate cardiac and brain functions, neurotransmission, response to inflammation, some have antihypertensive properties, and some promote plant cell growth and cell division. In addition to these, other applications include use in DNA-based nanomaterials and wires, for extension of the genetic alphabet, and as probes of biological function. In the medical field, nucleosides have been at the forefront in the control/treatment of viral diseases and cancer, against emerging viral diseases and bioterrorism. These serve to exemplify the importance of nucleosides and their analogs.

Thus, it is of high importance to develop new and facile ways to modify nucleosides and nucleoside derivatives, so that new applications can be sought with novel molecular entities that become available via chemical approaches. In our laboratories we have been studying metal-catalyzed methods for the modifications of nucleosides. These approaches enable access to structural entities that are not otherwise readily available. Primarily, the types of chemical reactions that have been studied involved carbon-carbon and carbon-nitrogen bond formation, and importantly, we have also studied the use of the existing nitrogen atoms in the purine structure to conduct more remote functionalizations of purine nucleoside derivatives. We have also pursued in parallel some uncatalyzed nucleoside modification methods, as that approach is intimately connected to the overarching goals of accomplishing nucleoside modifications. Furthermore, some of our research has led to a fundamental understanding of chemical processes that have much broader applicability in organic chemical methodology, and we have explored some of these broader applications. Importantly, these are potentially useable by researchers worldwide in many different contexts. Finally, our research has led to the identification of novel and potentially more sustainable approaches for nucleoside modification that can be explored in greater detail in the future.

The City College of New York (CCNY) has a very diverse student population. A significant proportion of students at CCNY are underrepresented in the scientific workforce. Our research program has historically served an ethnically diverse student body, providing state-of-the-art training to male and female students at all levels of education: undergraduates, MS, 5-year BS/MS, and Ph.D. students. Undergraduates, MS and 5-year BS/MS students gain hands-on training in the chemical sciences such as reaction design, reaction setup and workup, product isolation and characterization, and troubleshooting. In addition, they also gain a fundamental understanding of chemical processes and "how to make chemistry work". They also obtain hands-on experience with handling contemporary research equipment. All these better prepare these students to either directly enter the workforce or to undertake additional studies at a higher level. Ph.D. students also gain comparable experiences but at a higher level of complexity, so as to make them capable of leading the scientific endeavor in the future.
